item.title: God is With Us
item.description:
The only constraints on this sermon were that it be between 15 and 25 minutes long, and be on a text from the Old Testament. Audio is recorded with Ferrite, using an iPhone SE placed on the podium.

Audio

Download

Video

God Is With Us (John 14:15‚Äì31) from Chris Krycho on Vimeo.

God Is With Us

Introduction

I was recently reading a long article on President Obama‚Äôs foreign policy, and something caught my attention as I was reading through the article. There‚Äôs a great scene where they‚Äôre sitting on a plane in another country, and people are waiting for the President to get off the plane, and the reporter tries to prod him that it might be time to leave, and the President just keeps talking. And what struck me was that relationship, where he could prod the President that maybe it‚Äôs time to leave. You don‚Äôt get that kind of relationship by standing up in the middle of a White House press conference and demanding up-close and personal access. You get it because the President initiates it and invites you to have it with him.

There‚Äôs a fairly obvious analogy to our friendship with God here, and you may well have heard it before. But it rings true. And more than true, in this case: it‚Äôs as if the President came and said, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm going to make you a room in the White House. But in the meantime, I‚Äôm going to come live with you and share everything I have with you.‚Äù

As we read through the passage, look for two things, our two themes for this evening:

  1. We love and obey God
  2. God dwells with us

Again: we love and obey God and God dwells with us.

Body

Read with me, starting in verse 15, and on down through verse 31:

If you love me, you will keep my commandments. And I will ask the Father, and he will give you another Helper, to be with you forever, even the Spirit of truth, whom the world cannot receive, because it neither sees him nor knows him. You know him, for he dwells with you and will be in you.

‚ÄúI will not leave you as orphans; I will come to you. Yet a little while and the world will see me no more, but you will see me. Because I live, you also will live. In that day you will know that I am in my Father, and you in me, and I in you.

Whoever has my commandments and keeps them, he it is who loves me. And he who loves me will be loved by my Father, and I will love him and manifest myself to him." Judas (not Iscariot) said to him, ‚ÄúLord, how is it that you will manifest yourself to us, and not to the world?‚Äù Jesus answered him, ‚ÄúIf anyone loves me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our home with him. Whoever does not love me does not keep my words. And the word that you hear is not mine but the Father‚Äôs who sent me.

‚ÄúThese things I have spoken to you while I am still with you. But the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name, he will teach you all things and bring to your remembrance all that I have said to you.

Peace I leave with you; my peace I give to you. Not as the world gives do I give to you. Let not your hearts be troubled, neither let them be afraid. You heard me say to you, ‚ÄòI am going away, and I will come to you.‚Äô If you loved me, you would have rejoiced, because I am going to the Father, for the Father is greater than I. And now I have told you before it takes place, so that when it does take place you may believe. I will no longer talk much with you, for the ruler of this world is coming. He has no claim on me, but I do as the Father has commanded me, so that the world may know that I love the Father. Rise, let us go from here.

I. We love and obey God

Throughout this passage, we see those two themes: we love and obey God, and he dwells with us. And they always seem to come in that order.

Look at verse 15:

If you love me, you will keep my commandments. And I will ask the Father‚Ä¶

Or verse 21:

Whoever has my commandments and keeps them, he it is who loves me. And he who loves me will be loved by the Father‚Ä¶

Or verse 23:

If anyone loves me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him, and make our home with him.

And by the same token:

Whoever does not love me does not keep my words.

Now, our obedience doesn‚Äôt bring about the Spirit filling us. Our obedience isn‚Äôt why God dwells with us. In fact, it‚Äôs Jesus‚Äô obedience to the Father, going to die at the hands of the ruler of this world, down there in verse 30, and his resurrection, which we see in verses 18‚Äì20, which make fellowship with God possible.

But clearly, our obedience matters. It‚Äôs constantly tied to God‚Äôs dwelling with us in this passage. Jesus opens with it because he was talking with people who did love him. This is comfort in the midst of what is about to be a very difficult trial. When they might feel left alone like orphans, and needed to known they were his, and he would come back to them.

So why obedience? Because it is a sign of love. We see that at the end of the passage, in Jesus‚Äô love for the Father and his obedience flowing out of that. And we can see it in our own lives, too. If my daughters are dishonoring their mom by disobeying her, there is something wrong with their love for her. Sometimes when we are talking to or disciplining our three-year-old, we tell her, ‚ÄúHey, your loves have gotten out of order.‚Äù She is loving good things, but in the wrong proportions.

And we all do that. When we don‚Äôt obey God, when we don‚Äôt keep his commandments, it is precisely because we our loves are disordered or mis-ordered. We love things in the wrong way, or we have love them with the wrong priority. Above all, we love other things more than our Father. Not like Jesus.

What does it look like when we do love God?

  1. For one, knowing his words. You can‚Äôt keep them if you don‚Äôt know them!
    • Read the Bible
    • Talk about what Jesus said with friends and family, just as part of the ordinary course of your day.
    • Memorize Scripture, so it‚Äôs there in your mind as you go through life.
  2. Practice daily obedience to his words‚Äînot just the flashy, exciting kind, but the ordinary ways we seek holiness.
    • Be kind to your neighbors.
    • Go to church.
    • Love your in-laws well.
    • Tell others the good news of all that Jesus has done and will do.
    • Help your kids with their homework even when you‚Äôd rather be reading, and don‚Äôt be grumpy at them.
    • Deal with your children graciously, kindly, and patiently, even when disciplining them.
    • Give generously to support the church and missions work.
    • Give generously to those who are in need, period‚Äîto whomever asks.
    • Forgive others when they do you wrong.
    • Tell others of this great hope and joy!
    • Live in community with other believers: be open to correction, and to encouragement‚Äîand give the same!
    • Repent of your sins, both privately and publicly.
    • Serve where there are needs.
    • Turn the other cheek and bless those who curse you.
    • Do your work whole-heartedly, for the sake of the God who dwells in you, and not for man!
    • Be honest and truthful in your financial and professional dealings

And remember, that‚Äôs not a list of ways to get into God‚Äôs good graces. It‚Äôs a list of ways we respond because we are are already in God‚Äôs good graces. Those are things we do because we are confident we are loved. We show him our love by our joyful obedience.

But in truth, we find that hard. We need help, dealing our disordered and our mis-ordered loves. We forget that we are loved. We forget that we‚Äôre not alone, orphans in a cold world.

II. God Dwells With Us

But we‚Äôre not. God dwells with us. That‚Äôs the hope, and the help, that we need. God dwells with us.

Look at that question there in the middle: Judas (not Iscariot) asks, ‚ÄúLord, how is it that you will manifest yourself to us, and not to the world?‚Äù That‚Äôs a good question. And what Jesus does here is take his first answer, and carry it even further out of the realm of what Judas understood then.

Jesus opens this passage, having just told them how he is going to go away to the Father and prepare a place for them, and he says, ‚ÄúI will ask the Father, and he will give you another helper‚Äù (another advocate, or a friend-in-court, someone to carry you through the trial) ‚Äúto be with you forever.‚Äù The disciples were where, I think, any of us would be in their shoes. Jesus says he‚Äôs ‚Äògoing to his Father‚Äô? What does that mean? Are we going to be alone?

A few weeks ago, I traveled for work, and I ended up being gone for about a week and a half. I have two little girls, and one of them was about nineteen months old then, and she was a wreck after that. For weeks, every time I went near the door‚Äîif I so much as went to take out the trash, she would lose it. She didn‚Äôt understand where I had gone, or why, or when I was going to come back. And she loves me. She didn‚Äôt want me to leave again. She wanted me to be with her.

That‚Äôs where the disciples were. It makes sense. That‚Äôs why Jesus told them, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to leave you as orphans. I will come to you.‚Äù

But when Jesus explains how he will come to them: ‚ÄúI will ask, and the Father will send you a Helper, and he will be with you. The world won‚Äôt see me, but I will show myself to you,‚Äù you can see where Judas‚Äô confusion comes from. Jesus‚Äô answer, and really this whole passage, points us to something‚Ä¶

I can‚Äôt fully capture all this passage says. I have wrestled with it for weeks, and there is just so much here. I can‚Äôt capture it. Look at verse 23: ‚ÄúIf anyone loves me,‚Äù Jesus says, ‚Äúhe will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our home with him.‚Äù

I can‚Äôt give you a summary, but maybe a window, looking at an ocean.

God dwells with us.

God‚Ä¶ dwells‚Ä¶ with us.

I said ‚Äúa window on an ocean‚Äù because the depths here‚Ä¶ More than an ocean, there is a universe of depth here. There are depths here which we will never finish plumbing. We could, for eternity, dive deeper, and deeper into that reality. We will for eternity dive deeper. But we will never exhaust its depths. We will never say, ‚ÄúOh: that‚Äôs how deep the love of God goes; that‚Äôs where it stops.‚Äù And this mystery? There is more.

God dwells with us.

If you‚Äôre a believer, if you love God and keep his commands, this ocean is yours. And friend, listen: if you‚Äôre hearing this word and you don‚Äôt yet love God‚Äîyou‚Äôre not keeping Jesus‚Äô words‚Äîthis is what is freely offered to you: in Jesus‚Äô first dwelling with us in the Incarnation; in his life, obeying the Fathers‚Äô plan all the way through to his death on our behalf; in his resurrection; in his asking the Father to send the Spirit‚Äîsalvation offered freely to you. The God who has always been, the God who exists in eternal love in the Trinity, wants to dwell with you. So turn from your rebellion against God, and love God‚Äîand know that you are loved by him!

He promised them they would see him again (in verses 19‚Äì20), a pointer to the resurrection. But more than that, we see in his promise of peace, and even in his telling them ahead of time that he was leaving, preparation for the time when he would have ascended. Like now. We don‚Äôt see Jesus with these eyes.

But we still need to know we‚Äôre not orphans. We still need peace, and not like the world gives it. We need God to be with us.

Imagine there were a way I could tell my little girls, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going away to do some work for you, but even while I‚Äôm gone, I will come to you.‚Äù Isn‚Äôt that what Jesus does here? ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to my Father to prepare a place for you‚Äù but now, to your distress about that: ‚Äúthe Father and I will come to you.‚Äù

How? ‚ÄúI will ask the Father,‚Äù Jesus says in verse 16, ‚Äúand he will give you another Helper, to be with you forever, the spirit of Truth‚Ä¶ he dwells with you, and will be in you.‚Äù

The Spirit of the living God: his breath; our helper, our advocate and friend-in-court; our teacher, who will remind us of everything Jesus said to us, who inspired these Scriptures and now applies them to us; the peace that we need.

Because Jesus didn‚Äôt go away and leave them orphans. He didn‚Äôt leave us orphans.

God dwells with us, because his Spirit is with us and in us. And just as the Father and the Son are one (as we see both earlier in this chapter, and again here in verses 20 and 24) the Spirit is one with the Father and the Son. They act together, but it‚Äôs more than that. The way Jesus talks in this passage: ‚ÄúWe will come to him, and make our home with him‚Äù; or the way Paul talks in Ephesians: ‚ÄúYou are being built together into a dwelling place for God by the Spirit‚Äù. Where the Spirit is, the Father and the Son are, too.

So when the Father does as the Son asks, and sends us the Spirit to dwell with us, he is giving us himself. We have access in one Spirit to the Father. When someday we are glorified, and heaven has come down to earth, and the dwelling place of God is physically with man, when we can see the risen Lord with our own eyes‚Äî

The Spirit will still dwell with us. He is with us forever. He is our union with God. Jesus is in the Father, and we are in him, and he is in us‚Äîthrough the Spirit.

We somehow‚Äîagain, depths beyond us‚Äîwe participate, through the Spirit, in the life of God.

He, mystery of mysteries, he wants to dwell with us.

Conclusion/Exhortation

As we close tonight, three things to take away.

  1. Reflect. John wants us to reflect on this mystery: God has made us his home. God dwells with us.

  2. Obey. If we love him, we‚Äôre going to obey Jesus‚Äô words. So remember that as we go out from here. Keep his word‚Äînot to persuade God to love you, but because he already does love you, because he already dwells with you, because you and I together are his temple and his tabernacle. So keep his word. Demonstrate (like you would to a friend or a child or a spouse, but so much more) that you love him.

  3. Peace. As we go out from here, we might think to say, ‚ÄúGod be with you!‚Äù But perhaps better, in light of this passage, to say, ‚ÄúGod is with you. Go in peace.‚Äù

item.title: A Strange and Messy Deliverance
item.description:
The only constraints on this sermon were that it be between 15 and 25 minutes long, and be on a text from the Old Testament. Video and its audio are from an old MacBook Pro pointed at the podium. Dedicated audio is from my iPhone in my shirt pocket.

Audio

Download

Video

A Strange and Messy Deliverance (Judges 3:7‚Äì31) from Chris Krycho on Vimeo.

Prayer

Let us pray. Gracious Father: thank you for revealing yourself to us, especially in your Son, our Lord; and for filling us with your Spirit so that we may know you truly. As we come to your word tonight, help us know you more deeply and worship you more faithfully. In Christ‚Äôs name, amen.

Introduction

Please open your Bibles to Judges, chapter 3. And as you turn there, I want you to think about these words:

Boring exegesis must be wrong when the texts are so obviously full of life.

Again:

Boring exegesis must be wrong when the texts are so obviously full of life.

That‚Äôs N. T. Wright, speaking of the Pauline epistles. But I think, equally applicable whenever we come to God‚Äôs word‚Äîespecially in preaching and teaching‚Äîand most especially when the texts are like this one: lively, to say the least; strange, even.

I have two goals for this sermon. The first‚Äîalways the first‚Äîis to show the grace of God clearly. As Bryan Chappell, the author Christ-Centered Preaching, puts it, we want to see how God did for his people then what they could not do for themselves; and through that to be be reminded of what he has done for us, that we could not do for ourselves. That‚Äôs the point of this sermon: God‚Äôs grace in Christ.

But secondarily‚Äîthinking about boring exegesis; thinking about hard texts like Judges 3‚ÄîI hope to encourage you that these texts, these strange texts, these sometimes difficult texts‚Äîthey‚Äôre for us, and for our good. They‚Äôre for our people, and our people‚Äôs good. We don‚Äôt need to ashamed of them, or embarrassed by them, or intimidated by them. Rather, we can come away seeing how these texts magnify the grace of God, how these texts remind us to look to Christ.

Body

Othniel: The first judge

So let‚Äôs look and see. This is a long passage, with three judges‚ÄîOthniel, Ehud, and Shamgar‚Äîso we‚Äôll take each in turn. Read with me, starting in verse 7:

And the people of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the LORD. They forgot the LORD their God and served the Baals and the Asheroth. Therefore the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia. And the people of Israel served Cushan-rishathaim eight years. But when the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, the LORD raised up a deliverer for the people of Israel, who saved them, Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb‚Äôs younger brother. The Spirit of the LORD was upon him, and he judged Israel. He went out to war, and the LORD gave Cushan-rishathaim king of Mesopotamia into his hand. And his hand prevailed over Cushan-rishathaim. So the land had rest forty years. Then Othniel the son of Kenaz died.

This first narrative is probably the easiest to understand. Othniel is the first judge. He is the prototype for all the other judges that follow. His story shows out the pattern for the whole book, the same one the author laid out back in chapter 2: sin, discipline, a cry for mercy, and God‚Äôs deliverance through a judge.

Verse 7: Israel sins. They forgot Yahweh their God. They served the Ba‚Äôals and the Asheroth instead of the God who had delivered them from Egypt.

That‚Äôs an interesting word choice: forgot‚Äîand it‚Äôs an important word, not only in this passage, but throughout the Bible. After all the reminders in the covenant: Set up these stones so you remember! Teach your children, so they remember. Bind it on your hands and your forehead, so you remember! And they forgot.

Othniel is Caleb‚Äôs brother, note. They forgot in the first generation they were in the land.

When we forget, we get things wrong. You‚Äôve seen it happen: a spouse forgets an anniversary, and spends some time ‚Äúin the dog house.‚Äù Or parents who miss a school event for their children, and leave them feeling like they don‚Äôt matter. Forgetting a friend‚Äôs birthday: maybe you‚Äôre not as close as you thought.

And sometimes‚Ä¶ we all forget who God is, what he has done for us, and what our relationship to him is as the covenant people of God. We find ourselves fixated on the approval of the people in the pews, on the applause of subscribers to our popular podcast, on the affirmation of our professional peers. We become idolaters‚Äîjust like Israel.

But he showed them mercy. How? ‚ÄúHe sold them into the hand of Cushan-rishathaim, king of Mesopotamia‚Äù‚Äînot mercy the way we might be inclined to think of it, but real, deep mercy.

Because: see what happens? It had the intended effect. They remembered Yahweh and called out to him. And he delivered them‚Äîboth from the pagan King, and from their idolatry, at least for a time! The Spirit came on Othniel, and he led Israel to war, and God delivered them from Cushan-rishathaim, and they had peace for forty years.

God delivered his people, and Othniel, this first judge, was a good judge. He wasn‚Äôt a prophet like Moses; he didn‚Äôt give them lasting rest, any more than Joshua had (40 years is good, but it‚Äôs not forever); and he didn‚Äôt circumcise their hearts. Not the judge then. A good judge, but not the judge.

Ehud: The assassin

Sadly, he was also the best of the Judges. Things only go downhill from here. Who‚Äôs next? Ehud: the assassin. Let‚Äôs read again, picking up in verse 12:

And the people of Israel again did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, and the LORD strengthened Eglon the king of Moab against Israel, because they had done what was evil in the sight of the LORD. He gathered to himself the Ammonites and the Amalekites, and went and defeated Israel. And they took possession of the city of palms. And the people of Israel served Eglon the king of Moab eighteen years.

Then the people of Israel cried out to the LORD, and the LORD raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite, a left-handed man. The people of Israel sent tribute by him to Eglon the king of Moab. And Ehud made for himself a sword with two edges, a cubit in length, and he bound it on his right thigh under his clothes. And he presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man. And when Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent away the people who carried the tribute. But he himself turned back at the idols near Gilgal and said, ‚ÄúI have a secret message for you, O king.‚Äù And he commanded, ‚ÄúSilence.‚Äù And all his attendants went out from his presence. And Ehud came to him as he was sitting alone in his cool roof chamber. And Ehud said, ‚ÄúI have a message from God for you.‚Äù And he arose from his seat. And Ehud reached with his left hand, took the sword from his right thigh, and thrust it into his belly. And the hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade, for he did not pull the sword out of his belly; and the dung came out. Then Ehud went out into the porch and closed the doors of the roof chamber behind him and locked them. When he had gone, the servants came, and when they saw that the doors of the roof chamber were locked, they thought, ‚ÄúSurely he is relieving himself in the closet of the cool chamber.‚Äù And they waited till they were embarrassed. But when he still did not open the doors of the roof chamber, they took the key and opened them, and there lay their lord dead on the floor.

Ehud escaped while they delayed, and he passed beyond the idols and escaped to Seirah. When he arrived, he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim. Then the people of Israel went down with him from the hill country, and he was their leader. And he said to them, ‚ÄúFollow after me, for the LORD has given your enemies the Moabites into your hand.‚Äù So they went down after him and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites and did not allow anyone to pass over. And they killed at that time about 10,000 of the Moabites, all strong, able-bodied men; not a man escaped. So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest for eighty years.

We see the same pattern again here‚Ä¶ sort of. We see Israel sin, and God discipline them. And we see Israel cry out to their covenant God, and we see him deliver them.

But of course, Ehud‚Äôs story is more complicated than Othniel‚Äôs was. Some of the details here might initially perplex us. Why do we hear about how fat the king is? Why do we hear about the dung coming out after he gets stabbed? Why almost any of the extraneous-seeming details in this story?

Well, this is satire. (Which doesn‚Äôt make it untrue, of course.) The author plays up the ridiculous elements in this bit of history to make a point.

What do we see here?

A conquering king! ‚Ä¶

  • who‚Äôs actually morbidly obese, not exactly a strapping warrior
  • who, so cunning he could forge an alliance with the Ammonites and Amalekites, gets fooled by a simple trick (‚ÄúOh king, I have secret message for you‚Äù)‚Äîhe‚Äôs either hopelessly naive or profoundly overconfident; neither is good
  • a man who so comically out of line with what a king should be that his servants don‚Äôt even notice when there‚Äôs a wretched stench and he takes a looong time relieving himself

Great king.

And his servants? They aren‚Äôt exactly top-drawer. They don‚Äôt even notice Ehud escaping after he assassinated their king‚Ä¶

If we read the story right, it‚Äôs humorous. The author is poking fun at the Moabites! ‚ÄúThose Moabites!‚Äù

Right?

But, wait‚Ä¶ those Moabites conquered Israel. This ridiculous Moabite king?‚Ä¶ Ehud was there to bring him tribute.

Israel is the real joke. The idolaters who got conquered by this king. Ouch.

This is what good satire does. It sneaks in, makes you laugh, and then hits you where it counts.

And what about Ehud himself? What about this savior figure? He‚Äôs not good either. He‚Äôs a vicious assassin, a traitor who stabbed the man he was legally supposed to be serving.

This story is messy. Not just because of the dung coming out. But because while yes, God did deliver his people, and that is good‚Äîbut Ehud isn‚Äôt the kind of deliverer we want, not the kind of deliverer we need.

Not the brutal killer, but the one who was brutally killed.

Not the one who defeated a foreign king by stabbing him in the gut, but the one who overcame both the pagan oppressor and the idolatry that led to that oppression by being stabbed, by taking the weapon to his gut.

The book of Judges shows us over and over again what we‚Äôre like left to our own purposes. How even our human saviors are woefully insufficient. The covenant hope, proclaimed from the start of Genesis and made so clear in Deuteronomy‚Ä¶ was still waiting to be fulfilled.

Shamgar & Unifying Theme

And then we come to the end of this chapter‚Äîto Shamgar: the man with an ox-goad and his one verse: verse 31.

After him was Shamgar the son of Anath, who killed 600 of the Philistines with an oxgoad, and he also saved Israel.

So if you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôre wondering at least two things about this passage. One is: what in the world is an oxgoad? That‚Äôs the easy one: It‚Äôs a cattle prod. A long wooden pole with a point on the end. Makes for a decent improvised spear.

But the other question, the bigger question, is why does Ehud get paragraphs, with lurid details for a satire‚Ä¶ and Shamgar gets just one sentence?

We have a man who, based on his name, doesn‚Äôt even seem to be an Israelity, who shows up, kills 600 Philistines with an ox-goad, and then he‚Äôs gone. He gets one mention in Deborah‚Äôs song in chapter 5, but basically, this is it.

So why mention him at all if he‚Äôs so seemingly unimportant? Why these proportions?

After all, this is the inspired word of God. And the author had a reason for giving us these stories, even these proportions. He‚Äôs making a point.

We read this and I, for one, think, ‚ÄúOh, that sounds interesting; how did he do that with a cattle pr‚Äî‚Äù ‚ÄúNO. That‚Äôs not the question.‚Äù He slams the door on that question.

Shamgar‚Äôs skill with an ox-goad is not the point, any more than Ehud‚Äôs skill as an assassin was the point, any more even than Othniel‚Äôs skill as a military leadership was the point. No more, I put it to you, than any of us are the point.

‚ÄúAnd he also saved Israel.‚Äù Those words tell us what we need to know. Who saved Israel? Shamgar‚Ä¶ Ehud‚Ä¶ Othniel‚Ä¶ but really, in every case, Yahweh. The covenant-keeping God, who saved Israel not only from 600 Philistines, not only from a Moabite king worthy of derision, not only from a mighty king of Mesopotamia‚Äîbut from her idolatry.

Summary and Exhortation

Someday‚Äîsomeday, after many judges, many kings, many priests, many prophets‚Äîthere would come a deliverer‚Äîa judge, a prophet, a priest, a king‚Äî

  • who would give the land rest, who would give the people of God true rest, for more than just a generation; forever‚Ä¶
  • who would be a wise king
  • who would be gentle and gracious ruler
  • who would give God‚Äôs people circumcised hearts
  • who would fulfill the covenant hopes and take on himself the covenant curses of Deuteronony, of Exodus, of Genesis

We have that deliverer. We have Christ. ‚ÄúAnd he also saved Israel.‚Äù So when we read, when we teach, when we preach, let us look, every time, and see what God did for his people that they could not do for themselves. Let us, in every passage, in every picture of grace, find a reminder of what God has done for us in Christ, that we could not do for ourselves.

We have a deliverer. Don‚Äôt forget. Don‚Äôt let your people forget. We have a deliverer.

Gracious Father: thank you for delivering us. Help us be faithful with your word. Help us remember, and help us remind your people, of how you have delivered us. In the name of Jesus, our savior, amen.

item.title: A Humble, Selfless, Unity
item.description:
The only constraints on this sermon were that it be between 15 and 25 minutes long, and be on a text from an epistle. Video is from an old MacBook Pro pointed at the podium.

Audio

Download

Video

A Humble, Selfless Unity (Philippians 2:1‚Äì11) from Chris Krycho on Vimeo.

Good evening. Let‚Äôs pray before we begin.

Gracious God, may your word be clear in our hearts. May your Spirit open our minds to see you more clearly and love as you have loved us. May we see you, and may I not obscure you. Thank you for revealing yourself to us.

Introduction

Our text for this evening is Philippians 2:1‚Äì11. It might be a familiar passage to many of you, but I think it might also be a surprising passage to you. It was for me.

I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôve ever been walking along someplace familiar and had something prompt you to stop and notice something about your surroundings that you had never seen before. Maybe you went back to the house you grew up in, and the house is the same, but you aren‚Äôt‚Äîand you notice the little cracks in the ceiling. Were those always there? You look at the wall in your older sister‚Äôs bedroom. Was it always that color? I thought it was lighter than that. You go down the stairs into the basement, and ‚ÄúYup, they always creaked like that,‚Äù your mother tells you. You start to ask about the way the basement smells and she just shakes her head at you.

It had been a while since I read this passage, and it kind of felt like thinking you had grown up in a really nice house and going back and discovering that it was mansion. But whether you‚Äôve read this passage a hundred times, or this your first time opening a Bible, God is inviting us into a beautiful mansion tonight.

1. Believers called to humble, selfless, unity (2:1‚Äì5)

As we come to Philippians 2, Paul has just spent the first chunk of a letter to these Christians in Philippi‚Äîgood friends to him, people who have supported his ministry‚Äîabout his circumstances‚Ä¶ which aren‚Äôt great, frankly. He wrote this letter from prison. But, one way or another, he has seen a great many people hear the good news about Jesus as a result of his in prison. But he also knows that the Philippians are having a hard time, and he knows that they need encouragement in their faith. He knew that when things get hard‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs persecution, physical or mental illness, death among your friends or family, losing jobs‚Äîwhen life gets hard, we can turn on each other. And Paul called the Philippians, in the midst of their trials‚ÄîGod is calling us, tonight, in the midst of our trials‚Äîto something different: to a humble, selfless, unity.

Let‚Äôs read:

1So if there is any encouragement in Christ, any comfort from love, any participation in the Spirit, any affection and sympathy, 2complete my joy by being of the same mind, having the same love, being in full accord and of one mind.

Four reasons

Paul opens with four reasons for people to live with this humble, selfless unity. ‚ÄúIf there is any‚Ä¶‚Äù

  1. encouragement in Christ
  2. comfort from love
  3. participation in [which could also read fellowship in or with] the Spirit
  4. affection and sympathy

‚ÄúIf there is any,‚Äù he says. Is there any? Well, yes. There is encouragement in Christ. We do find comfort from being loved, by God and by each other. As believers, we do have fellowship with the Spirit, and through him with Christ and the Father, and of course with each other too. We do have God-given affection and sympathy for each other, and even for non-believers.

In other words, Paul is using that ‚Äúif‚Äù to quietly point the Philippian believers to a reality. When he asks them to complete his joy if these things are true, he‚Äôs saying, ‚ÄúLook, these four things are true.‚Äù You do encouragement; comfort; fellowship; affection and sympathy. And just as they did, so do we.

So given those four good reasons, Paul asks them to complete his joy. As he has told them already, earlier in the epistle, he already has great joy‚Äîin seeing the gospel go forth. He even rejoices when people preach the gospel in an attempt to make him jealous. But his joy isn‚Äôt complete without something else. If these four reasons are the foundation for that completion, the finished building is humble, selfless, unity. But what we might ask: what is the structure of that finished building?

Three ways

There are three. Four foundation stones, and three pillars on that base. Paul told his friends they would complete his joy‚Äîthey would fill it up‚Äîby:

  1. being of the same mind
  2. having the same love
  3. being in full accord and of one mind

(If you‚Äôre worried about my counting: affection and sympathy go together, and so do ‚Äúbeing in full accord and of one mind.‚Äù If you have true affection for someone, you will feel sympathy for her when she is struggling. If you‚Äôre in full accord with someone, it‚Äôs like you and he share a mind. So: four foundation stones, and these three pillars.)

And what we see in these three pillars is that these three ways are really one way. They‚Äôre one structure. And that one way, is to be one. That one way is unity. Joy, for the apostle, and I think it is fair to say God‚Äôs joy in our fellowship, is complete when we are truly unified. Not identical, but unified.

But how? How do we have the same mind? How do we have the same love? How can we be in full accord and of one mind? That seems rather abstract. If I sat down my three-and-a-half year old and my 20-month old and said, ‚ÄúOkay, Ellie and Kate, you need to have unity between you two,‚Äù they would just stare at me. Ellie, the older one, might say, ‚ÄúYes, daddy!‚Äù just to be good, but they wouldn‚Äôt know what to do with it. Kate, the younger one, would probably yell ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù because she‚Äôs a toddler and we‚Äôre working on that right now. And wherever you are: whether you‚Äôre saying, ‚ÄúOkay‚Ä¶‚Äù but you don‚Äôt really get it, or you‚Äôre saying ‚ÄúNo, no way! Have you met these people?‚Äù Paul draws us forward. He gives us some help, makes it a little more concrete.

Two contrasts

Paul gives us two pairs of contrasts to help us see a little more clearly what this kind of unity looks like. Capstones to match the foundation, if you will.

3Do nothing [, he says in v. 3,] from selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility count others more significant than yourselves.

That‚Äôs the first capstone, the first contrast. Not selfish ambition, not conceit, but humility, and counting others more important than yourself. So we see first that this unity is humble unity. It comes becomes I‚Äôm valuing you above me. I‚Äôm not trying to exalt myself. I‚Äôm thinking of how I can make you do well instead.

Verse 4 shows us the second contrast, the second capstone:

4Let each of you look not only to his own interests, but also to the interests of others.

This unity, then, is also selfless. When we‚Äôre healthy, we don‚Äôt just aim to get our own. ‚ÄúLooking out for number one!‚Äù No, instead, we help others accomplish their hopes. We give of our time; our money; our sleep; our space ‚Äì to help others.

So this is the church. This is the kind of building we‚Äôre supposed to be. As Paul puts it in Ephesians, we‚Äôre being built together into a temple for God‚Äîa temple of people known for their humble, selfless, unity‚Äîtheir love.

We have these four foundations: encouragement in Christ, comfort from love, fellowship with the Spirit, and affection and sympathy. We have three pillars of unity: being of the same mind, having the same love, being in full accord and of one mind. We have two capstones: calls to humility and selflessness.

But you might be asking now, ‚ÄúHow? I want that unity; I even want to be selfless and humble, even if that sounds kind of hard. But I don‚Äôt know how.‚Äù And to that, Paul says, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry; I‚Äôll give you an example. In fact, here is the example.‚Äù And he shows us Christ‚Äîverse 5: ‚ÄúHave this mind among yourselves, which was also in Christ Jesus‚Ä¶‚Äù

2. The foundation of humble, selfless, unity (2:6‚Äì11)

The mind of Christ! That‚Äôs a heady thing to think about. But for Paul, it‚Äôs deeply practical, in fact. He gives us a very succinct summary of Jesus‚Äô ministry. And what was Jesus like? He was humble. He was selfless. (And if you‚Äôre thinking, ‚ÄúBut what about unity?‚Äù you‚Äôre right. Hold on to that thought. We‚Äôll come back to it.) Let‚Äôs start by looking at Christ‚Äôs example.

Christ humbled himself

6who [Christ Jesus], though he was in the form of God, did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped [‚Äîsomething to be held onto‚Äî], 7but emptied himself, by taking the form of a servant, being born in the likeness of men. 8And being found in human form, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross.

What we see here is one of the great mysteries our faith. God became man. We could take a dozen sermons on this point alone. But Paul has something very specific for us to see from the Incarnation here. Whatever prerogatives we might have‚Äîwhatever money, whatever fame, whatever position or status‚Äîthe Son had more. And Jesus Christ lived as a servant. He didn‚Äôt hold onto what was his (and it really was his, by right!). He came as one of us. When you read here, ‚Äúin the likeness of man,‚Äù don‚Äôt think ‚Äúhe was kind of like us.‚Äù Hebrews tells us that he was exactly was we are‚Äîyet without sin.

And that degradation goes down and down and down. He became a baby, who needed to be changed. He dealt, like my older daughter does, with younger siblings who tormented him. He was teased by other children. He went through puberty and had his voice go all scratchy. He worked for many years in obscurity. When he started his ministry, he was rejected as often as accepted, loved for his miracles and not for the God he revealed, mocked even by his own family, and wandered around without a home. Remember, the God of all the universe. And ultimately, he died. Died a sinner‚Äôs shameful death. He took our humiliation. And through all of it, he did not complain, he just served. So Christ is our model.

A convicting model, at least for me. Jesus, the real flesh-and-blood Jesus who was tempted just like us, is the perfect man. He is what it means to be human rightly. And he served. He‚Äôs the rightful king! And he served. Do I serve like that? Do you? Or do we demand our rights?

The Father exalted Christ

Now, as we come into these final verses, we see what at first might seem like a bit of a strange turn. Paul is trying to teach us about this kind of humble, selflessness,‚Äîand yes, unity. Hmm. And we were tracking along, as we saw the concrete example of Jesus living and dying selflessly. Feeling conviction, even; I certainly was and am. But then we get to this:

9Therefore God has highly exalted him and bestowed on him the name that is above every name, 10so that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, in heaven and on earth and under the earth, 11and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.

This is, at first blush, a bit of a challenge. ‚ÄúOkay. I mean, it‚Äôs good that Jesus is exalted. But how does it fit? Am I going to be exalted? Am I supposed to serve because Jesus was exalted? What‚Äôs going on here?‚Äù

There are two parts to this. One of them is, yes, that Jesus is Lord. We are citizens of his kingdom, and if his people lived like that, his people should certainly live like that. So that is one part of it.

But there is something else going on here, too.

And this‚Äîoh, this! What do we see here? We see the Father exalting the son. He highly exalted him. He gave him the name that is above every other name. The Father wants every one to say, ‚ÄúJesus is Lord!‚Äù The Father wants everyone to bow down and worship Jesus. And Jesus, the Son‚Äîhe‚Äôs doing all of this, he‚Äôs becoming a servant, taking on human nature, dying, on a cross to what end? To the glory of the Father!

We have a little glimpse here into something‚Ä¶ awesome. We see the Father, saying to the Son, ‚ÄúLet me exalt you!‚Äù And Jesus says to the Father, ‚ÄúAll the glory is yours!‚Äù And the Father to the Son, and the Son to the Father, back and forth, and back and forth, forever. This is the life of the trinity. This is the eternal life of the triune God: humble, selfless, unity! Love!

And this is what we‚Äôre meant to be. This is what the church is for. This is what humanity is for: men and women made in the image of God‚Äîhumble, selfless, unity.

The life of the Trinity, in the life of the church. This is the building we‚Äôre meant to be. This is the temple. This is the mansion.

Paul has taken our question: ‚ÄúHow do I live like that?‚Äù and he‚Äôs answered it by showing us how the life of the triune God took on flesh, and lived among us. Was our servant. Died for us. He says: ‚ÄúHow Christ lived is how we are meant to live.‚Äù And he reminds us, back there in v. 1: ‚ÄúIf there is any encouragement in Christ, any comfort from love, any participation in the Spirit‚Äîany fellowship with the Spirit, remember; any affection and sympathy, complete my joy‚Ä¶‚Äù We have fellowship with the Spirit. That‚Äôs where our unity comes from: not common interests, not shared experiences, not being the same age, or sex, or ethnicity, or social standing, or economic status.

We‚Äôre meant to be a little picture, every day, of the Trinity. And the way we do that, is by living like Christ did. We choose, every day, to serve the people around us, instead of ourselves. We choose, every day, not to put ourselves first, but to put others first. We choose, every day, not to make ourselves look great, but to love others.

Exhortation

Brothers and sisters, here is my challenge to you today. Fill up your joy, and fill up my joy, and fill out our Triune God‚Äôs joy in you!‚Äîby loving one another as he has loved us. This kind of humble, selfless, unity is not a burden. It is what we are for. And yes, in this fallen world, it is hard sometimes. But we have the Spirit. We participate in God‚Äôs own love. Mystery‚Äî awesome mystery! Let us love one another. Let us count one another more important than ourselves. Let us look not only to our own interests, but to each other‚Äôs. Let us live in the humble, selfless, unity of our King‚Äôs kingdom.

And friend, if you are not a believer, and you look at this picture, I hope you‚Äôre thinking, ‚ÄúYes. That‚Äôs what the world ought to look like.‚Äù Because it is. And it‚Äôs beautiful. We‚Äôre not meant not for self-absorption. We‚Äôre meant to live like Christ did. So I challenge you: call Christ lord. Let his death be yours, and his resurrection, too‚Äîcome walk after him with us.

Let us pray to our loving, selfless, humble God of unity.

God we praise you, who are love and light forever. Thank you for your love‚Äîfor sharing it with us, humbly and selflessly; for drawing us into your love and restoring us to what you designed us for. Thank you for building us into a temple for your Spirit. Help us walk in this same humble, selfless unity.

item.title: Power and Mercy
item.description:
The Bible exposition class for which I prepared this sermon involves writing but not delivering a sermon. If, at some point in the future, I actually deliver this sermon (e.g.¬†in my sermon delivery course next semester), I will update this post with a link to the audio and/or video.

Introduction

Recent estimates suggest that the United States of America currently spends about three times as much money on our military as the next biggest military spender out there, China. In fact, if you add up the military spending of China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, France, Great Britain, India, and Germany, we still spend more. And remember, China‚Äôs and India‚Äôs populations are both over four times larger than ours. What‚Äôs more, corruption and graft notwithstanding, our military-industrial complex is incredibly advanced. It‚Äôs fair to say that America has the most powerful, best equipped, most effective military apparatus in the whole world.

And yet. And yet, as a country, we are very afraid. All of that power can‚Äôt protect us from everything. And we are very feared. For all of America‚Äôs lofty ideals, we have made a mess of things pretty often. We‚Äôve gotten it wrong. Having power, it turns out, isn‚Äôt enough. Having enough power matters, but so does having the right kind of power, and so does how you use that power.

As we look at Mark 5:1‚Äì20, we‚Äôre going to see that play out. It‚Äôs not just having power that matters. It matters who has the power, and how they use it. Do they torment? Or do they show mercy?

I‚Äôll give you a hint: we want power coupled with mercy. You can see, if you look at verse 19, how this whole passage hinges on that. When all is said and done, the man in the middle of this story gets to go tell all his friends and neighbors how much the Lord had done for him‚Äîhow powerful God is‚Äîand how the Lord had shown him mercy.

Exposition

Context

So let‚Äôs see how Mark gets us there. As we come to our text, we read: ‚ÄúThey came to the other side of the sea, to the country of the Gerasenes.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe other side of the sea from what?‚Äù you might be asking. Well, from Galilee, where Jesus had been teaching. Back at the beginning of chapter 4, Mark tells us about a series of parables that Jesus taught about his new kingdom. And those parables particularly emphasized people‚Äôs response as his kingdom comes. Some reject it entirely; some look excited about it at first, but ultimately aren‚Äôt a part of it; and some, a few, really are citizens of the new kingdom.

Then, back in 4:35, Mark switched to a series of narratives‚Äîfour stories. This is Mark‚Äôs basic strategy: tell us what Jesus said, and then show us what he did. Why? Well, because the parables weren‚Äôt just cryptic things Jesus said to confuse people; he was telling his disciples, the ones who had ears to hear, how things really were. Each thing Jesus did showed that what he said was true.

His kingdom wasn‚Äôt coming the way people thought, or even to the people who thought it was for them. And he wasn‚Äôt the kind of king they had in mind, either. He had authority not just over nations and troops, but (as Mark shows us in these four stories), over the sea and the sky, over demons‚Äîthat‚Äôs today‚Äôs passage‚Äîover incurable illness, even over death. And in each of these events, we see that Jesus wasn‚Äôt just a powerful king. He was also a merciful king.

Now, within these four narratives, Mark breaks things down into two pairs of miracle stories which hang together: the storm and the demonized man, and the two healings back on the other side of the sea. Today, we find ourselves in the second half of that first pair. With the storm, the disciples could not save themselves, so Jesus rebuked the storm, and there was a great calm, and the disciples were afraid. We are going to see those same ideas here: someone who cannot save himself, Jesus rebuking something, a great calm as a result, and people being afraid. We will see Jesus‚Äô power and mercy. And we will see a different response than fear‚Äîa better one.

Beat 1: A wild man ‚Äì 5:1‚Äì6

So let‚Äôs follow Mark on this journey. Verse 2 tells us that ‚Äúwhen Jesus had stepped out of the boat, immediately there met him out of the tombs a man with an unclean spirit‚Äù. Verse 6 reiterates the point‚Äî‚ÄúAnd when he saw Jesus from afar, he ran and fell down before him‚Äù‚Äîbut first Mark wants us to know something about who this man was. Verses 3 through 5 tell us:

He lived among the tombs. And no one could bind him anymore, not even with a chain, for he had often been bound with shackles and chains, but he wrenched the chains apart, and he broke the shackles in pieces. No one had the strength to subdue him. Night and day among the tombs and on the mountains he was always crying out and cutting himself with stones.

In other words, this was not a man in need of a little help, an appointment with a counselor. No, here we have a man enslaved. Nothing anyone could do would help him.

What we have here is Mark establishing both the characters involved, and the ‚Äúpower curve‚Äù for the rest of the scene. If you‚Äôre reading a superhero comic or watching a superhero movie, you have a sense of how strong everyone is. And of course, this leads to all sorts of conundrums. Who would win in a fight? Next year‚Äôs Batman vs.¬†Superman: Dawn of Justice and Captain America: Civil War both hinge on this. Who is stronger? Who will win? And of course, if you let the wrong characters in, the game just becomes pointless. I saw an interview with the writers behind Captain America, where they explained why the Hulk wouldn‚Äôt be in the movie. You add in the Hulk, and it‚Äôs game over for the other team. There‚Äôs no tension in the conflict anymore. The Hulk just wins.

And that‚Äôs basically the picture Mark shows us in this passage. It‚Äôs pretty clear: the demons were stronger. Nothing anyone could do was effective. They couldn‚Äôt even keep this man imprisoned; verse 4 has him acting like, well, like the Hulk. They tried chaining him up hand and foot; he just ripped the chains on his wrists off and smashed the fetters on his feet. ‚ÄúNo one,‚Äù Mark says, ‚Äúhad the strength to subdue him.‚Äù Healing him was out of the question. And the man himself was clearly totally under the demons‚Äô control. The ‚Äúsuper-villains‚Äù had the upper hand.

Now, the Hulk can be kind of fun to watch, but that‚Äôs not what we have here. They made a mockery of this man. We shouldn‚Äôt take that lightly. They made him run around screaming, naked, cutting himself, in the midst of the tombs. There is a reason Mark describes him as having an unclean spirit. The demons were doing everything in their power‚Äîshort of killing this man‚Äîto defile what God had called ‚Äúvery good‚Äù and what he had promised to redeem: his humanity.

So there‚Äôs the power curve when Jesus arrives on the scene; there are the characters. As soon as Jesus gets off the boat, this man comes out to meet him. And then, perhaps surprisingly, given that power curve‚Äîbut then again, maybe not so surprising given what Jesus has already done in this gospel‚Äîverse 6 tells us that the man falls down at his knees before Jesus. He goes prostrate. Flat on his face. The way you would kneel before someone absolutely more powerful than you. Jesus‚Äô arrival is clearly a change from the status quo.

Beat 2: A merciful act ‚Äì 5:7‚Äì13

Setup

So Mark has set the scene for us: here is a man who has been tormented for who knows how long, and as soon Jesus steps off the boat, he man comes running up and throws himself down at Jesus‚Äô feet. That‚Äôs quite the welcoming party. Put yourself in the disciples‚Äô shoes for a moment. You‚Äôve just seen Jesus go from sleeping in the back of a boat‚Äîin the middle of the kind of storm that scared the Galilean fishermen who are with you‚Äîto standing up and telling a storm to be quiet and it does. You‚Äôre afraid. And then you get to the other side, still more than a little in shock from that, and a naked man with cuts all over his body comes up to Jesus and throws himself at his feet and starts arguing with him, shouting at him. You might be afraid all over again. And for good reason. Notice that throughout the whole passage, the disciples are just onlookers. This is out of their league, too; so they just watch.

Beat 2a: Jesus‚Äô power ‚Äì 5:7‚Äì10

Dealing with the man and his impure spirit is not, however, out of Jesus‚Äô league. Verses 7‚Äì10 make it very clear that Jesus is absolutely and unquestionably the most powerful person in this encounter.

Notice, too, that the demonized man is arguing with Jesus because Jesus is arguing with him. Verses 7 and 8 tell us:

He shouted at the top of his voice, ‚ÄúWhat do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? In God‚Äôs name don‚Äôt torture me!‚Äù For Jesus had said to him, ‚ÄúCome out of this man, you impure spirit!‚Äù

Jesus picked this fight, and it‚Äôs not going to go down well for the demons.

Now we know from ancient records that there were both Greek and Jewish exorcists who made it their business to drive out evil spirits. You will find the same in many non-Western cultures today, and‚Äîas an aside‚ÄîI think those cultures probably have the right of it more than we do. It has been said that the greatest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing people he didn‚Äôt exist, and that seems about right. How can you possibly fight something you don‚Äôt even believe exists? It‚Äôs a brilliant, devious strategic move. You can pull the North Korea strategy‚Äîtry to constantly rattle your saber to keep everyone afraid of you. Or you can act like an assassin: keep a low profile, and if possible don‚Äôt even let your would-be opponents know you exist, until you‚Äôve killed them and caused mayhem. In the hyper-secular West, that seems to be the satanic strategy of the hour, and I think it‚Äôs fair to say it‚Äôs been reasonably successful for our enemy‚Äîeven if we know from passages like this one that Jesus‚Äô ultimate victory is guaranteed.

That wasn‚Äôt the strategy of the day back then, though. And we know from those old records that the general strategy for dealing with demons was to try to use powerful command words and phrases, or to negotiate and bargain, or to use the demon‚Äôs name to get spiritual power over them, or to try to use other divine powers to bind them.

But we don‚Äôt see any of that in this passage. The demons recognize Jesus‚Äô power and authority right away. You can see it there in verse 7: as soon as Jesus tells them to leave, they plead with him not to torment them. And you don‚Äôt plead with someone not to torment you unless they can torment you. By the time Jesus asks for a name in verse 9, the demons have already acknowledged Jesus‚Äô power and authority in the situation. What‚Äôs more, they call him ‚ÄúSon of the Most High God‚Äù there in verse 7. Now, this title does double duty here.

First, it is another confirmation of Mark‚Äôs claim throughout his gospel: that Jesus is in fact the Son of God. And significantly, the early confessions to that effect all come on the lips of demons he exorcises. The spiritual forces know spiritual authority when they see it, even if the people don‚Äôt see it yet. So confirming that Jesus is ‚Äúthe Son of God‚Äù is the first thing this does.

The second thing it does is establish that Jesus isn‚Äôt just another player in the spiritual game. Whatever other gods someone might worship, and whatever other claims to divine power someone might offer up, Jesus trumps them all. He is the son not just of some god, but of the Most High God.

The fact that there is a legion of demons, as they admit in verse 9, simply heightens the contrast. We knew already that the ‚Äúimpure spirit‚Äù was able to torment the man; now we know that it is many demons. It doesn‚Äôt matter. They‚Äôre still reduced to begging and pleading with him: verse 10 tells us that the man‚Äîreally, the spirits speaking through him‚Äî‚Äúbegged Jesus again and again not to send them out of the area.‚Äù

Again, the power curve: Jesus‚Äô authority isn‚Äôt even in the same ballpark as anyone else in the story‚Äînot the demonized man, not the people who were unable to help him or even restrain him, not the silent disciples, and not even the multitude of demons. He exceeds them all.

Beat 2b: Jesus‚Äô focus ‚Äì 5:11‚Äì13

A few years ago, John Piper was preaching a missions sermon, and he started with Mark 5:19. You can see why. It‚Äôs the heart of the gospel. And Piper summed up the heart of the gospel this way:
